SP.P: Now for the claret, and the hock! odd's my life, these are the customers! none of your port-drinkers, nor your eighteen-pen'orths of half-and-half! a body may pay scot and lot, maintain half a dozen soldiers for government, and put a trifle in one's pocket to boot, out of this sort of guests!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter General FAIRLOVE, Attendants, and Servants.

SP.SPEAKER: GENERAL.
SP.P: Come, look sharp, look sharp! there's my good lads! clap me four of the freshest horses you have to a post-chaise directly; it's too late to advance in the phaeton:—and be brisk, d'ye hear? for I must continue my march in a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Kindly welcome, Sir! won't your honour please to be shewn a room, and have your boots off?—here, boot-catcher! what would your honour please to drink after your journey?—Wil∣liam, shew the Captain into the castle.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: Thank you, thank you, good woman!— as you were, lads! I shan't go into garrison here, nor halt the firing of three rounds:—bring me some ammunition, tho'; a sponging of brandy, a charge of cold beef, a bumper or two of sound old hock; then I shall be fit for action, and may do execution if I reach the works.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: But, won't your honour please to be shewn a room?

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P:
No, no, dame! I shan't halt a moment; so, a truce with trifles and ceremony. I am not
come to quarter a score of raw-boned troopers on you: I am upon the march!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Bless me, your honour's hurrying way puts me all over in a flusteration!

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: I am in as great a flusteration, as you call it, dame, as you can be; so, come, come!—give me what I call'd for, that I may remount. (WILL. brings the GEN. brandy; he drinks.) Sure I shall overtake them before night!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Overtake who, your honour! if I may be so bold? not deserters, I hope! poor souls, how they will be punish'd!

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: No, no, not deserters, good woman; re∣fugees only! that's the corps I am in pursuit of: so, tell me, what parties have gain'd this pass lately?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: I profess, your honour is too high-flown for me; I can't say I comprehend your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: No?—why, zounds! what travellers have gone by here to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: O, a power, your honour! of all sorts and sizes! it being such a charming fine day, I sat at the door an hour or two, and saw more go by than I can well remember.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: Well, those you can remember; what corps did they belong to?—Come, describe their uniforms.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: An't please your honour, I don't think they were at all uniform; for, first and fore∣most, there pass'd by a fine, tall, handsome serjeant, with four or five tag-rag recruits, a corporal, and drummer; a string of Irish hay-makers, and the little Welsh attorney.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: Platoons to the recruits, and mask'd-bat∣teries to the attorney! did no women come this road to-day, in a post-chaise?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Women in a post-chaise?—O, yes; one woman, your honour, and a lady along with her.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: One woman and a lady! Oh,—now we approach the lines; well, which way did they take their route? what downs are they encamp'd on?— or, do they lie in ambuscade any where here∣about?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Indeed, your worship, I am but an ignorant body; and, as I said before, your honour's talk is too learned for me.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: Damn these professional phrases; they make blockheads appear wise, and men of sense fools! why, Madam, to speak in terms more level to your apprehension; I believe you have describ∣ed the identical persons I am in pursuit of: two young women, one of them appearing, no doubt, like a lady; the other, as you observed, may seem to be only her woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Why, then, your honour, as sure as can be, they are the very couple that dined here to-day;—and a sweet, good creature the lady is: —ay, and a brisk, clever kind of body the other.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: What, and have they decamp'd?—'Sfire! I mean, are they gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Yes, your honour, they have been gone some time, to the play.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: Play! what the devil does the woman mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Why, the comedy, I think they call it, your honour! the actors are now playing in our assembly-room theatre.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN,
SP.P: Zounds! shew me the way to it directly! I'll try if I can't play a part too—

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: This way, your honour, this way.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: March!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Bless my heart, what a flutter has this blustering put me into! I shan't recover my∣self this half-hour. (sits) Here, chambermaid! Betty!

DIV3.P: Give me a thimble-full of that brandy, yonder, William brought for Captain Bounce-about.

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am.

STAGE.HI: Goes to the bar for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Come, be quick; don't creep so! you are as slow as the Captain's hasty: (MAID pours a little brandy into the glass.) and as niggardly as old Rackrent!—is that all you can afford me of my own liquor?

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: You said only a thimble-full, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: I know I did, Ma'am! but I didn't say a child's thimble-full; you might, at least, let my own thimble be the measure: (drinks) this inn-keeping is such a fatiguing life; give me a drop more. (drinks again) If I go on thus my spirits will soon be exhausted!—Where's Frank.

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Ma'am! is the girl stupid?— where's my son? where's your young master?

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: I believe, Ma'am, he's gone to take a peep at the play.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: Hang the play, and the players too! If I did not get pretty handsomely by them, I should wish them far enough!—such a racket they make;—I can hear them now: enough to dis∣tract a body! with their stamping, and staring, and fighting, and dying! they almost turn the house out at the window.

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: Indeed, Ma'am, they do make a strange hurly-burly sometimes, sure enough.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Oh, Ma'am, there's the devil to pay in the play-house; the folks are all in an uproar.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: What, with that harum-scarum-officer, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am; for, as we went along, he ask'd me whereabout the young lady was seat∣ed? so, I shew'd him to the box; when, in he bolts directly, snatches hold of her hand, and calls her his dear creature! the lady scream'd, 'Squire Edward, my young Master, and the rest intersered; and, in the scuffle, the lady fainted! the officer is gone to Justice Rackrent's for a warrant; and how it will end nobody knows.—O, here they come!—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter EDWARD and MARIA, leading CHARLOTTE.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Reach a chair for the lady somebody.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Here's one, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: Have you any hartshorn, pray, Ma∣dam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: O dear me, no! but here's some sal volatile.

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Thank Heaven, she recovers!

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: How do you find yourself now, my dear lady?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: How fares my angel?

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: O, Sir, why will you thus persist in troubling me? why expose me to public insult, and drive from me my health, my senses!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P:
Be composed, dear Madam, and deign to look on me; it is not the rude intruder now addresses you, but your protector; who, to gain
an interest in your heart, would sacrifice his own.

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: No matter who, or what you are; my heart's elsewhere disposed of.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: O, say not so! and, pardon me, sweet creature! if I presume to say, I do not think it is.

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: (rising) Sir, your ill-manner'd contra∣diction suits not with your appearance; and you are now equally offensive with the other stranger you rescued me from: if you're a gentleman, de∣tain me here no longer.—Maria, let us go.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Stay, Madam, I conjure you;—and hear me but a moment!

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: Pray, let the gentleman speak to you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: What can he have to say that I should need to hear?

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: No matter; pray, consent!

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: Well!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Eternal blessings on you for that word! —and now permit me, dearest Madam, to repeat, and pray be not offended at it, that I have great reason to suppose your affections are not elsewhere engaged; nay, I overheard your confidante de∣clare so: therefore, as I otherwise may never see you more, I here intreat you to impart your name, and your connexions, and give me leave to hope!

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: All this my own imprudence has drawn on me!—but I will be explicit.—You think, per∣haps, Sir, that I am a woman of fortune;—you are deceived: I am an indigent orphan!—so very poor, I have not even a heart! no, that too is lost! and so romantically. (half aside)

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P:
(overhearing her) Romantically indeed! —and, since this is the case at last, I am deter∣mined
that all shall out.—Sir, we are neither more or less than a couple of adventurers; virtuous, tho', take that with you!—but, my silly partner in the scheme has declined going through with the project; having fixed her affections on some booby of a peasant, she met and conversed with this after∣noon, in the grove.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: (with stifled transport) On a peasant in the grove? impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: O, Sir, with shame I own all that my friend has said is true! Yet, as a declaration of my sentiments, might have entailed misery on us both; I had the resolution, leaving a memorial of me, to fly from him and love!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Behold again, sweet maid! the blest me∣morial.

STAGE.HI: Shewing the ring she had given him.

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: (looking earnestly in his face.) Amaze∣ment! you were not sure the peasant!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Yes, my adored! and, having such a proof of your regard, my hand, heart, fortune, are at your disposal!

SP.SPEAKER: DOR.
SP.P: Oh, your honour! oh, 'Squire Edward! I thought as how it were you, had gotten into this priming-iron wi' the strange leady.—Such a to-do!—I wish the leady, and you, and the leady's leady, and poor I, and all of us, aren't sent to jayl, and tried at next excises!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: What's the matter, Dorothy?

SP.SPEAKER: DOR.
SP.P: Why, your honour! there be com'd a great officer, all bedaub'd wi' gold lace, to aks his worship, your father, to grant un a warrant to take you all up! but where he do mean to set you down, old scrat and himself only knows!

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: Gracious Heaven! what will this end in?

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: I protest I begin now to be frighten'd too!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Pray, dear Madam! pray, young gen∣tlewoman! compose yourselves; if you will confide in my protection, I will immediately place you in security, and return to the event.

SP.SPEAKER: DOR.
SP.P: 'Las-a-daisy, your honour! you canno' budge a stp! they be at door by this'n!—but, don't ye be terrified, sweet my Leady! nor you, Mem! nor you, 'Squire Edward! I'se do all I can to help you, indeed; I run'd here before 'em, while warrant were making out, on purpose: Timothy being to serve it, and we being cater∣cousins, I'se sure, an I do speak a good word for you, he won't be outrageous:—and, indeed, I'se do all I can to serve you!—By the mass! here they do come;—pluck up a good heart now, sweet my Leady!

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: Sir, I know not what to think of this; and must rely on your protection!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Be not alarm'd, I beg, Madam! I'll protect you with my life!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter TIMOTHY, with a constable's staff, and warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: TIM.
SP.P: Young 'Squire Yedward Rackrent! I aks pardon for my bouldness; but, being head∣borough, and having a warrant, I apprehend and seize you in the King's Majesty's name!— moreover, and saving respect, I apprehend and seize you, my Leady!—and you, young gentle∣woman!—and you—no! I don't seize no more— hem!

SP.SPEAKER: DOR.
SP.P:
(aside.) Bless us! what a fine figure our
Timothy do cut, now that he be in power! if I warn't in such a teaking, I cou'd admire his meek∣ness and audacity!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: I'm astonish'd!—are you serious, Ti∣mothy? apprehend and seize us! for what?—and by whose authority?

SP.SPEAKER: TIM.
SP.P: By your father, the worshipful Justice Rackrent's authority; and for high-treason for aught I do know.—One of the King's officers made oath, and said, he has a right to seize that lady wherever he can find her.

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: To seize me!

SP.SPEAKER: TIM.
SP.P: Yes; and he'll tell you so himself, for all you be so pratty! as soon as ever his worship, who is coming with him, can hobble here!— therefore, be advised by a friend, 'Squire Yed∣ward, and ha' no more to say to her; for, thof she looks so like an angel, 'tis my belief she's a Turkish spy!

SP.SPEAKER: DOR.
SP.P: (aside.) A spy!—nay, then, I be sure I won't say one word for her, let Timothy be ne'er so outrageous; for fear I shou'd be taken up for a'complish!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter General FAIRLOVE, old RACKRENT, and FRANK.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: (as entering.) Nay, but, Sir! pray, hear reason.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANK.
SP.P: Ay, do, landlord!

SP.SPEAKER: RACK.
SP.P:
Don't talk to me, any of you! but shew me to him! where is this bully? this bra∣vo? this Hector of a son of mine? I'll teach him better manners than to affront an officer! a gene∣ral! a generalissimo, for aught I can tell! how shou'd we landed and monied men be safe in the possession of our property, without the
protection of the military? I'll teach the vil∣lain—

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, there's no occasion for your being so warm; I requested your assistance as a magistrate only, and justice should always be cool—I am not so old, but I can take satisfaction for personal injuries myself.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Nor I so young, Sir, but I can give you satisfaction for any injury, you may imagine you have received from me!

SP.SPEAKER: RACK.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, sirrah! don't dare to speak a word more in my presence!—I have heard the whole affair; a riot in the play-house, indeed! but, I'll put a stop to the play!—I'll have no more of it!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: What, Sir! would you distress a whole community, for a casualty, which they were in∣nocent of?

SP.SPEAKER: RACK.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, I say!—I have also heard of your being the champion of this para∣mount-puppet! as a punishment for which, I here declare, and I desire all parties present to take notice of it, that I disinherit you! I'll cut you off with a shilling, sirrah! and, that I may be sure you will have no more, I'll sell my estates; and, when I die, be buried ten fathom under ground, and have all my money buried along with me!

SP.SPEAKER: FRANK.
SP.P: Ten fathom under ground!—egad, if you are buried twenty, I believe, Beelzebub will find you out.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: There, Madam! you hear the determi∣nation of your protector's father:—now, will you prefer love and poverty with him, or ease and affluence with me?

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P:
Sir, I cannot conceive on what pre∣tence you ground your insolence; and, as no one
living can have a right to controul, or detain me, I beg I may be permitted to leave this place, without farther molestation. (Going.) Come, Maria!

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: Stay, Charlotte!

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: Ha!—he knows my name!

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: By my sword, honour, and affection! I believe I have been so eager to recover my dear child, that I have not had thought enough to tell her, what I am certain she could not know un∣told; and, instead of flying to the arms of her fond, anxious father, perhaps she has mistaken me for a troublesome, ridiculous, old lover.

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: What said you, Sir?—father!—can my father be alive?

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: Ay, my sweet girl! I am he! Gene∣ral Fairlove, your doating, happy father!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Then, I am undone!

SP.SPEAKER: FRANK.
SP.P: And I too, egad, for aught I know! he's not my turtle's father, I hope!

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: I no sooner arrived in London, than I was told, that you had read in the public prints, an account of the ship I came home in being lost; and, being also inform'd of your abrupt depar∣ture, having traced you to the inn you set out from, I instantly pursued, and have, here, hap∣pily regain'd my darling child, my Charlotte!

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: Oh, Sir! this is not a place wherein I can properly express my filial feelings! but, for∣give me, I beseech you, Sir, that so many years absence, with the belief that you were dead, should have made me not recognize my ever∣honour'd parent!

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P:
I should not have known you, dear! when I accosted you so inconsiderately at the
play, if circumstances had not assured me, that you were my own Charlotte Fairlove.

SP.SPEAKER: TIM.
SP.P: Oh, now the murder's out, Dorothy! the leady's no spy! I see plain enough; and, I suppose, your noble honour, I may let her go a∣bout her business?

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: You may, honest friend, with that for your pains.

SP.SPEAKER: TIM.
SP.P: Thank your right honourable worship, kindly!—Well, Dolly, ben't I a pure fellow, now! and didn't I bluster bravely?

SP.SPEAKER: DOR.
SP.P: Ay, that you did, Timothy! and, thof I say it to your face, I ha' see'd many an over∣seer, and churchwarden, when they were bul∣locking of the poor, not look half so big.

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: Your goodness, Sir, emboldens me to beg, that, however you may have reason to chide me for my late precipitate flight; as it has been productive of an unhappy breach between this young gentleman and his father, you will gra∣ciously consider him as the innocent victim of love and accident.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: (aside.) Generous creature!

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: I do, my child!—and, as I perceive your reciprocal affection, if your hand and fortune will atone for the loss of his father's favour, he may command them.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Sir, I know not how to thank you for your noble offer! and will my charmer deign to ratify such bounty?

SP.SPEAKER: CHAR.
SP.P: More willingly than ever wretch ex∣changed her misery for bliss!

SP.SPEAKER: FRANK.
SP.P: We have been silent spectators hither∣to, gentlefolks, as became us; but, now that one match is so happily concluded, I believe, with my mother's leave, another may be made up! and in fewer words.—What say you, Maria?

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANL.
SP.P: That's hardly a word at all.—Come, Maria! we have spoke plain English to one ano∣ther, hitherto; don't let us go about the bush now.

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: Why, then, thus it is—You have made pretty free with my lips, Frank; and, if I may judge by your present offer, are not displeased with the sample: here I am, just what I told you in the grove; honest, but poor: now, take me, or leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANK.
SP.P: What say you, mother? she's a clever wench, saith! let me have her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: And welcome, Frank!—she's a good girl, I believe, tho' frolicksome;—I'll give you a thousand pounds to begin the world with, and leave you five times as much when I die.

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: Well said, landlady; and, to convince you that you have not done amiss; her father, having repented his late harshness, authorised me to assure her of his concurrence in whomsoever should be her choice; adding, that they shall libe∣rally partake of while he lives, and, at his death, inherit his entire property.

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: My dear, good, little old dad!

SP.SPEAKER: FRANK.
SP.P: Perhaps, Maria, this may alter your mind?

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: No, Frank!—I like you!—and will make you as good a wife, as if I had not brought you a penny.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANK.
SP.P: Say you so, my girl!—why then, hey for Hymen! and, farewel inn-keeping! we'll now turn gentry, mother; and you shall also shortly turn—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. MILL.
SP.P: What? impudence!

SP.SPEAKER: FRANK.
SP.P: Grand-mother!

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: For shame, Frank!

SP.SPEAKER: GEN.
SP.P: Well said, young man! and, to keep you in countenance, old lady, my son-in-law looks a promise, as shortly to make me a grandfather.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: My present happiness, Sir, is so com∣plete, that it were avarice of bliss to think of fu∣ture felicity!—possest of my charmer's hand and heart, tho' blessings may be multiplied, the trans∣port of this moment can never be exceeded.

SP.SPEAKER: TIM.
SP.P: Saving your honours' presence, Dorothy and I be going to make a match on't too; and we'll do our best not to be behind hand with you.

SP.SPEAKER: DOR.
SP.P: Yes, your honours;—I'se always do my best; and be buxom at bed and board, as a good wife ought to be!

SP.SPEAKER: FRANK.
SP.P: Another happy-couple! well said! egad, I believe this is Valentine's day, for all the birds are pairing!—May we be loving as sparrows, cheer∣ful as linnets, and constant as turtle-doves; and may the cuckoo's note, "unpleasing to the mar∣ried ear,"—be never heard by us, but as the har∣binger of Spring.
